metadata.name: This fucking darkness #256
metadata.description:
A little secret and hidden project.

Use 'd' to watch the creation process.

metadata.name: Life #18
metadata.description:
I see life in my paintings. Black and white in my watercolor brush. Houses, roads and trees. Maybe nature maybe. 

+My unique paintings and JSON.

metadata.name: Released #52
metadata.description:
Today, minimalism is not just an art style, but a way to make positive changes in all of our lives. some people also believe that our current situation could be much simpler.
All people can feel liberated through minimalism. freedom from everyday worry and anxiety, from depression, and from the consumerism that engulfs us all.
press 's' to save original size

metadata.name: Unfolded #323
metadata.description:
A plane is repeatedly folded over itself, choosing creases either at random, or according to some pattern (like a grid). These creases form the boundaries of the individual textured tiles.

Once the folds are complete, they are undone in reverse order, recreating the original plane. With each unfolding, the orientation of each crease (as a mountain or a valley), and each tile (facing up or down) is recorded as a sequence of 1s and 0s. Tiles are colored and textured according to similarities in these binary sequences, giving rise to subtle symmetries and repetitions.

Written in vanilla JS & HTML5 Canvas.

Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Punktwelt #444
metadata.description:
Continuing on the theme of color perception in Farbteiler, Punktwelt is an exploration of color interaction, projection and perceived depth, and the aesthetics of simple Boolean operations on form.

Each shape is the result of a single block, a rectangular cuboid, subjected to a series of Boolean subtractions with other blocks, and rendered in parallel projection, oblique or axonometric, in the abstract landscape of the Punktwelt.

Some have horizons, some have banded or striped backgrounds. The unnatural drawing order and chromatic differences of the individual faces sometimes yields illusory or paradoxical visual geometries.

Press ’s’ to save a png. Press ’4’ to export a high resolution png. Press ’8’ to export a very high resolution png. Press ’e’ to export an SVG file (may take some time and produce large files).

Aspect ratio variations are 4:5, 5:4, 2:3, 3:2 and 1:1.

Built in Javascript with p5.js, p5.svg and csg.js.

metadata.name: Three dead trees on earth #26
metadata.description:
"Three dead trees on earth" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at PARIS+ par Art Basel.
This cycle is totally linked to my activity as a scientific researcher. Trees are data structures very much used in computer science and I worked on the random generation of these structures. It seemed interesting to me to make a link between the digital world (and these trees) and nature in danger. The 3 dead trees refer to the old beliefs of the south of France, while questioning us on the mutations of the world, and the risk to neglect our planet. Are the trees of the computer science the dead trees of our forests? To complete my work, I added a red sun, which is in fact a zonotopal subdivision (a complex mathematical object), that is to say a kind of tiling with rhombuses. I wanted to give a Japanese touch to my work, I love the minimalist poetry of Japanese gardens where everything is in its place and in harmony. Here, a desire to pay tribute to the work of Hiroshige.

metadata.name: GM.GEN.MATH #195
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke.
100% of the proceeds from primary sales are donated to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke. 
https://www.tribute-hwf.com/

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Undisputably, my mathematical background makes me naturally attracted to graphs, math functions, and transformations. I use math in ways that mathematicians could consider nonsense, but which produce fascinating aesthetic elements for creation (to paraphrase Herbert W. Franke). Combining scientific symbols and illustrations with fictional data produces pseudo-persuasive generative imagery that we can easily take to be absolute truth or in which we find meaningful patterns.
In the special issue of Leonardo, Visual Mathematics from 1992, Herbert W. Franke and Horst S. Helbig published the article Generative Mathematics: Mathematically Described and Calculated Visual Art.

They propose that “Through the use of [mathematical] formulas (software) we gain generative principles. Beyond formal descriptions, we obtain guides for the construction of images. For example, if we use a parametric representation of a curve, the result is similar to traditional methods of drawing and painting […]“ Additionally, mathematics removes frame limits and adds the possibilities for transitions, transformations, movement, and interaction by implementing simple changes to the defining parameters.

I’m also very fond of the analysis and comparison (mentioned there) of digitally generated images and Constructivist design. Limitations of the technology (in the 70s) allowed only simple line drawings, based on fixed proportions same as Constructivists did. “In a short time, all possible features were exhausted, so it became an obvious goal to try to extend them. This was done first by the use of random generators — a highly interesting expansion of design principles […]” Another expansion happened by adding curved shapes, first simple then complex that overcame possibilities of drawing with compasses and rulers. “[…] oscillating curves are easily obtained through mathematical formulas and computer-graphic systems. The results we achieve on this basis do not look like Constructivist presentations, but their rationality and precision derive from Constructivist principles. ”

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Each mint contains both dark and light version, use D/N keys to switch between “day & night”.
 
Base shapes are circles or Lissajous curves modified by the noise function. Shapes are arranged in a grid or by a circle packing algorithm. Lines are drawn smoothly or in stripes. Around 20% of the mints have lines in only one color (black/white). 

Depending on the browser/configuration rendering times will vary.

metadata.name: Flustels #102
metadata.description:
Fully generative artwork in crayoning style.

The model uses Perlin noise map multiplied by map with flowers.
Each flower generated randomly with circles and ellipses. 

Each token is 100% unique.

Traits:
- 20 color palettes;
- 5 compositions;
- 9 background styles;
- 2 brush weights.

Press 's' to save .png with resolution 2000px * 2000px.

Renders fastest in Chrome browser.

Made with p5js, math and love by @ivposure

metadata.name: Ode to Random #134
metadata.description:
This simple minimalist generative token is a tribute to randomness. The underlying grid, the start and end of the colored shapes, the color styles, the transitioning point from order to chaos, are randomized. The names behind the Styles of this token are derived from artists who have greatly inspired me, all or most of whom have incorporated randomness or chaos in their art in one way or another.

The price and number of editions were also chosen using a pseudorandom number generator.

Embrace the random!

Made in p5js
Created December 2021
Artist: @Yazid

metadata.name: Minimal complexity #298
metadata.description:
To celebrate the first anniversary
#fxhashturnsone

► 50% of primary sales are donated to the Processing Foundation.
► Features: Format, Mode, Palette, Padding, Division, Depth
► Press S to save a PNG

Made with p5js

metadata.name: fx(mash) #83
metadata.description:
fx(mash) is my humble contribution to celebrating #fxhashturnsone

This series is based on a simple algorithm - lines of a random length are drawn on a square grid until the grid is full.

I have added a variety of features based on some of my favorite fxhash projects and a few special guests.

This collection is intentionally diverse and disorderly, that's a nice way of saying I only had a short period of time following the release of Acequia. As a result, some of the outputs might be weird, messy, or even bordering on broken (if you get one of the latter please let me know and I'll reimburse you).

Despite being a bit rough around the edges, I hope fx(mash) reflects some measure of my love for the fxhash community. If you're feeling kind, then perhaps it even harks back to the experimental early days :)

The last year has been an incredible journey, thank you for letting me be a part of our story so far.

Controls (in live view):

- Press [s] to save the current image
- Press [g] to toggle grain
- Press [h] for a high-res output

Beta Controls (in live view, definitely not fully tested):

- Press [p] to start/pause animation
- Press [i] to slow down animation
- Press [o] to speed up animation

All primary sales go to Savepakistan.


Acknowledgements:

fx(mash) uses Gorilla Sun's grain implementation, a big thanks to him and meezwhite for a great article that is well worth supporting https://www.fxhash.xyz/article/all-about-that-grain

Thank you to the artists who created the following collections. Some were the source for palettes, others directly inspired traits, and some I thought would be fun to include as specific trait values.

Made with P5 and love, Lammetje 2022

metadata.name: Stunning Vibes #16
metadata.description:
A Mix of Images, a Mix of Colors, a Mix of Textures...
Stunning Vibes tries to create pieces that may touch you in a unique way, created in a generative way.

Walten, 25/11/2022

metadata.name: Unfolded #311
metadata.description:
A plane is repeatedly folded over itself, choosing creases either at random, or according to some pattern (like a grid). These creases form the boundaries of the individual textured tiles.

Once the folds are complete, they are undone in reverse order, recreating the original plane. With each unfolding, the orientation of each crease (as a mountain or a valley), and each tile (facing up or down) is recorded as a sequence of 1s and 0s. Tiles are colored and textured according to similarities in these binary sequences, giving rise to subtle symmetries and repetitions.

Written in vanilla JS & HTML5 Canvas.

metadata.name: Megalopolis #357
metadata.description:
Abstract artwork that generates urban-like structures viewed from the sky.

Options:

- press 'f' to toggle noise filter
- press 's' to save the PNG image of the current view
- press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to save hi-res PNG images

Created using p5js.

@VolatileMoods, May, 2022.

metadata.name: Slumbers #147
metadata.description:
Generative abstract artwork that explores forms, shapes, coloring and brushwork.

Options:

- press 'f' to turn off paper-like texture (recommended for print on hi-quality paper)
- press 's' to save the PNG image of the current view
- press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to save hi-res PNG images

Colors and textures might differ slightly on some devices due to the heavy use of low alpha blending. Calibrated and tested on Firefox 107.0 & Chrome 107.0.5304.107 on Win10 x64 Intel machine.

Created using p5js.

@VolatileMoods, November, 2022.
tags: slumbers volatile moods abstract generative painting colors brushwork

metadata.name: Dragons #136
metadata.description:
A grid of many lines forming a dragon crafted on paper.
They all have their own personality... Be sure to name and take care of them.

tw: williamapan

metadata.name: A Pixelated Dream Accumulations #17
metadata.description:
"An accumulation of the past pixelated dreams."

/////INTERACTIVITY/////
Do all the instructions below after opening the live mode.

1. To capture the screen, press the "c" button on your computer keyboard.

2. To save a 5-second .GIF from your iteration, press the "s" button on your computer keyboard. Please be patient while waiting for the piece to save and render its frames.

3. To adjust the piece resolution, you need to set your browser first and then reload the browser every time you want to capture the screen or save the rendered .GIF file.
///////////////////////

Created using Hydra and p5.js

Rangga Purnama Aji, 2022
https://linktr.ee/ranggapuraji
